description: Smallest number (>1) which appears at least n times in Pascal's triangle.
comments: Singmaster's conjecture is that this sequence is finite.
links: H. L. Abbott, P. Erdos and D. Hanson, On the numbers of times an integer occurs as a binomial coefficient, Amer. Math. Monthly, (1974), 256-261.
FTL Magazine, One Thousand and One Coincidences
D. Singmaster, How often does an integer occur as a binomial coefficient?, Amer. Math. Monthly, 78 (1971), 385-386.
David Singmaster, Repeated binomial coefficients and Fibonacci numbers, Fibonacci Quarterly 13 (1975) 295-298.
mathematica: (* Computation lasts a few minutes *) max = 4000; Clear[cnt]; cnt[_] = 0; Do[b = Binomial[n, k]; If[b <= max, cnt[b] += 1], {n, 0, max}, {k, 1, n - 1}]; sel = Select[Table[{b, cnt[b]}, {b, 1, max }], #[[2]] >= 1&]; a[n_] := Select[sel, #[[2]] >= n&][[1, 1]]; Array[a, 8] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Oct 05 2015 *)
